awd_titl_txt: The Effect of Particle-polymer Interactions on the Rheology and Structure of Dilute Particle-filled Polymeric Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
Solutions of polymer molecules and suspended solid particles are used in a range of products from paints and coatings to health care and foods.  The polymer molecules and the suspended particles act cooperatively to create a range of complex fluid behaviors that impact their processing.  While much is known about how particles and polymers act independently to alter fluid responses, little is known about their coupled effects.  This project will develop theories to predict 1) the stretching and alignment of polymer molecules by the disturbance to the flow caused by the particles, 2) how elongated solid particles or fibers align in the presence of polymers, and 3) the flow response of mixtures of particles and polymers.  The influence of flow rate, flow history, and flow geometry on the behavior of polymer-particle mixtures will be examined.  As part of this research, a graduate student and several undergraduates will receive training in fluid dynamics and theoretical and numerical methods. Both the principal investigator and the graduate student will participate in mentoring an undergraduate student from a group that is underrepresented in STEM fields.


The interplay of particle and polymer stresses will be explored in steady shear, oscillatory shear, and extensional rheology of suspensions of spheres and fibers in polymer solutions.  The hydrodynamic disturbance of the particles can dramatically alter the polymer conformation in the surrounding fluid while the polymer stress can lead to unexpected changes in the particle stresslet.  The rheology of fiber suspensions is strongly influenced by the orientations of the fibers. While previous theoretical studies have suggested that polymer stresses induce fiber alignment with the vorticity axis of a steady simple shear flow, experiments reveal a greater diversity of orientations even at low particle concentrations.  A search will be made for stable fixed orientations of fibers in simple shear flow and the dependence of the orientations on the rheological properties of the fluid.  The rheology of dilute particle-filled polymeric liquids will be determined using an ensemble averaged equation approach.  To facilitate quasi-analytic results, perturbation analyses based on small polymer concentration will be performed.  In contrast to previous studies that considered second-order fluids, this approach allows an exploration of the strain rate (or Deborah number) dependence of the rheology even while considering weak polymeric stresses.  Fully nonlinear computations using a finite volume method in a body-fitted coordinate system will complement the theoretical studies of fiber orientation in simple shear flow.  A variety of rheological models that include and exclude shear thinning and finite extensibility will be used to understand the effect that different polymer rheological properties have on particle-polymer interactions.  To broaden the diversity of future graduate students in the field, the PI and graduate student on the project will provide on-going mentorship throughout the undergraduate career of a prospective female or URM student from another university as well as offering undergraduate research projects on complex fluids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A polymeric fluid responds differently to various canonical flows due to its complex microstructure. In a simple shear flow, the polymers stretch and align with the fluid velocity direction thereby limiting further stretching.  However, the stress due to the polymers is much more dramatic in a uniaxial extensional flow, where the polymers align with the extensional axis and undergo a coil-stretch transition. In this project, we add particles to these two canonical flows of polymeric fluids and study the particle-polymer interaction. We find even more interesting physical mechanisms and behavior. These canonical flows are of practical importance as a particle-laden polymeric fluid undergoes uniaxial extension upon exiting the dye in extrusion molding or entering the pores in hydraulic fracturing. Simple shear flow of a particle-filled polymeric fluid occurs in many processing applications including injection molding, spin casting, and flow casting. Particles are added to these applications to impart anisotropy and increase the strength or electrical or thermal conductivity of the final product. In hydraulic fracturing, particles help to hold the fracture open.
 
We develop theoretical predictions for the resistance to extensional motion in dilute suspensions of spherical or prolate spheroidal particles in polymer solutions.  By expanding in small polymer concentration, we can obtain semi-analytical results over a broad range of the Deborah number, De, defined as the product of the extension rate and the polymer relaxation time.  At small De, the addition of particles increases the resistance to steady extensional motion because of wakes of highly stretched polymers downstream of the particles.  In contrast, when De is large, the presence of particles leads to a significant reduction in the suspension stress. This reduction is due to a reverse coil-stretch transition. The highly extended polymers far upstream of the particles collapse upon encountering the relatively quiescent regions near the particle surface. The same methodology also allows us to study the transient response of a suspension. Starting to stretch a suspension from its equilibrium state, the resistance to stretching increases monotonically with time at small De.  However, the behavior is non-monotonic for large De. We observe a significant transient increase in suspension stress for large De due to the wake of highly stretched polymers downstream of the particles.  Eventually, however, this wake diminishes, and the stress is reduced as polymer coil in the quiescent region near the particle surface.
 
Long, thin particles enhance the properties of a composite material anisotropically due to the orientation they adopt in the processing flow. The long axis of a particle rotates in a simple shear flow of a Newtonian fluid in one of a set of degenerate periodic paths called Jeffery orbits depending on its initial alignment.  We used a slender-body theory to find how polymer stresses break this degeneracy leading to final orientation states that are independent of initial conditions.  Depending on the Deborah number and the ratio of particle length to diameter, the final particle alignment can be either along the direction of the fluid velocity or along the vorticity direction (perpendicular to both the velocity and its gradient).  Furthermore, it can reach these final states either by spiraling across a series of Jeffery orbits of by rotating into the velocity-vorticity plane and then migrating within this plane.
 
As a complement to the theoretical analysis, we have developed a numerical code to solve the polymer stress and fluid velocity around a prolate spheroid. This code can be used to validate the theories and to provide predictions in fluids with higher polymer concentration and more complex time-dependent flow fields representative of industrial processing applications. This simulation is performed in a spheroidal coordinate system that rotates with the particle allowing one to capture the particle surface precisely as one of the coordinate surfaces. Hence, we can simulate flows around particles with much larger ratios of length-to-dimeter than are accessible with other methods.
